title: A modal logic translation of the AGM axioms for belief revision
abstract: Building on the analysis of Bonanno (2025) we introduce a simple modal logic containing three modal operators: a unimodal belief operator B, a bimodal conditional operator > and the unimodal global operator. For each AGM axiom for belief revision, we provide a corresponding modal axiom. The correspondence is as follows: each AGM axiom is characterized by a property of the Kripke-Lewis frames considered in Bonanno (2025) and, in turn, that property characterizes the proposed modal axiom.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In Bonanno (2025) a new semantics for both belief update and belief revision was provided in terms of frames consisting of a set of states, a Kripke belief relation and a Lewis selection function. In this paper we focus on AGM belief revision and make use of that semantics to establish a correspondence between each AGM axiom and a modal axiom in a logic that contains three modal operators: a unimodal belief operator B, a bimodal conditional operator > and the unimodal global operator \u25a1. sections.title: AGM axioms and their semantic characterization
sections.content:
We consider a propositional logic based on a countable set At of atomic formulas. We denote by \u03a6₀ the set of Boolean formulas constructed from At as follows: At \u2282 \u03a6₀ and if φ, ψ ∈ \u03a6₀ then ¬φ and φ ∨ ψ belong to \u03a6₀. Define φ → ψ, φ ∧ ψ, and φ ↔ ψ in terms of ¬ and ∨ in the usual way.
Given a subset K of \u03a6₀, its deductive closure Cn(K) \u2286 \u03a6₀ is defined as follows: ψ ∈ Cn(K) if and only if there exist φ₁, ..., φₙ ∈ K (with n ≥ 0) such that (φ₁ ∧ ... ∧ φₙ) → ψ is a tautology. A set K \u2286 \u03a6₀ is consistent if Cn(K) ≠ \u03a6₀; it is deductively closed if K = Cn(K). Given a set K \u2286 \u03a6₀ and a formula φ ∈ \u03a6₀, the expansion of K by φ, denoted by K+φ, is defined as follows: K+φ = Cn(K ∪ {φ}).
Let K \u2286 \u03a6₀ be a consistent and deductively closed set representing the agent's initial beliefs and let Ψ \u2286 \u03a6₀ be a set of formulas representing possible inputs for belief change. A belief change function based on Ψ and K is a function ◦ : Ψ → 2^Φ₀ (2^Φ₀ denotes the set of subsets of \u03a6₀) that associates with every formula φ ∈ Ψ a set K◦φ \u2286 \u03a6₀, interpreted as the change in K prompted by the input φ. We follow the common practice of writing K ◦ φ instead of ◦(φ) which has the advantage of making it clear that the belief change function refers to a given, fixed, K. If Ψ ≠ \u03a6₀ then ◦ is called a partial belief change function, while if Ψ = \u03a6₀ then ◦ is called a full-domain belief change function.
Definition 2.1. Let ◦ : Ψ → 2^Φ₀ be a partial belief change function (thus Ψ ≠ \u03a6₀) and ◦′ : \u03a6₀ → 2^Φ₀ a full-domain belief change function. We say that ◦′ is an extension of ◦ if ◦′ coincides with ◦ on the domain of ◦, that is, if, for every φ ∈ Ψ, K ◦′ φ = K ◦ φ.

sections.title: AGM axioms
sections.content:
We consider the notion of belief revision proposed Alchourrón, Gärdenfors and Makinson in Alchourrón et al. (1985).
Definition 2.2. A belief revision function, based on the consistent and deductively closed set K \u2286 \u03a6₀ (representing the initial beliefs), is a full domain belief change function * : \u03a6₀ → 2^Φ₀ that satisfies the following axioms: ∀φ, ψ ∈ \u03a6₀,
(K * 1) K * φ = Cn(K * φ).
(K* 2) φ ∈ K * φ.
(K * 3) K * φ \u2286 K + φ.
(K * 4) if ¬φ ∉ K then K \u2286 K * φ.
(K * 5)   if ¬φ is a tautology, then K * φ = \u03a6₀.
       if ¬φ is not a tautology, then K * φ ≠ \u03a6₀.
(K * 6) if φ ↔ ψ is a tautology then K * φ = K * ψ.
(K*7) K* (φ ∧ ψ) \u2286 (K * φ) + ψ.
(K * 8) if ¬ψ ∉ K * φ, then (K * φ) + ψ \u2286 K * (φ ∧ ψ).
K * φ is interpreted as the revised belief set in response to receiving the input represented by formula φ. For a discussion of the above axioms, known as the AGM axioms, see, for example Fermé and Hansson (2018), Gärdenfors (1988).

sections.title: Kripke-Lewis semantics
sections.content:
Definition 2.3. A Kripke-Lewis frame is a triple (S, B, f) where
1. S is a set of states; subsets of S are called events.
2. B \u2286 S × S is a binary belief relation on S which is serial: ∀s ∈ S, ∃s′ ∈ S, such that sBs′ (sBs′ is an alternative notation for (s, s′) ∈ B). We denote by B(s) the set of states that are reachable from s by B: B(s) = {s′ ∈ S : sBs′}. B(s) is interpreted as the set of states that initially the agent considers doxastically possible at state s.

sections.title: Modal AGM
sections.content:
3. f : S × (2^S \ {∅}) → 2^S is a selection function that associates with every state-event pair (s, E) (with E ≠ Ø) a set of states f(s, E) \u2286 S.
f(s, E) is interpreted as the set of states that are closest (or most similar) to s, conditional on event E.
Adding a valuation to a frame yields a model. Thus a model is a tuple (S, B, f, V) where (S, B, f) is a frame and V : At → 2^S is a valuation that assigns to every atomic formula p e At the set of states where p is true.
Definition 2.4. Given a model M = (S, B, f, V) define truth of a Boolean formula φ ∈ \u03a6₀ at a state s ∈ S in model M, denoted by s ⊨_M φ, as follows:
1. if p e At then s ⊨_M p if and only if s ∈ V(p),
2. s ⊨_M ¬φ if and only if s⊭_M φ,
3. s ⊨_M (φ ∨ ψ) if and only if s ⊨_M φ or s ⊨_M ψ (or both).
We denote by ||φ||_M the truth set of formula φ in model M:
||φ||_M = {s ∈ S : s ⊨_M φ}.
Given a model M = (S, B, f, V) and a state s ∈ S, let K_{s,M} = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : B(s) \u2286 ||φ||_M}; thus a Boolean formula φ belongs to K_{s,M} if and only if at state s the agent believes φ (in the sense that φ is true at every state that the agent considers doxastically possible at state s). We identify K_{s,M} with the agent's initial beliefs at state s. It is shown in Bonanno (2025) that the set K_{s,M} \u2286 \u03a6₀ so defined is deductively closed and consistent (recall the assumption that the belief relation B is serial).
Next, given a model M = (S, B, f, V) and a state s ∈ S, let Ψ_M = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : ||φ||_M ≠ Ø} and define the following partial belief change function ◦: Ψ_M → 2^Φ₀ based on K_{s,M}:
ψ ∈ K_{M} ◦ φ if and only if, ∀s′ ∈ B(s), f (s′, ||φ||_M) \u2286 ||ψ||_M.
(RI)

sections.title: Modal AGM
sections.content:
Given the customary interpretation of selection functions in terms of conditionals, (RI) can be interpreted as stating that ψ ∈ K_{s,m} ◦ φ if and only if at state s the agent believes that "if φ is (were) the case then ψ is (would be) the case”. This interpretation will be made explicit in the modal logic considered in Section 3. In what follows, when stating an axiom for a belief change function, we implicitly assume that it applies to every formula in its domain. For example, the axiom φ ∈ K ◦ φ asserts that, for all φ in the domain of ◦, φ ∈ K ◦ φ.
Definition 2.5. An axiom for belief change functions is valid on a frame F if, for every model based on that frame and for every state s in that model, the partial belief change function defined by (RI) satisfies the axiom. An axiom is valid on a set of frames F if it is valid on every frame F ∈ F .
Definition 2.6. We say that an axiom A of belief change functions is characterized by, or corresponds to, or characterizes, a property P of frames if the following is true:
(1) axiom A is valid on the class of frames that satisfy property P, and
(2) if a frame does not satisfy property P then axiom A is not valid on that frame, that is, there is a model based on that frame and a state in that model where the partial belief change function defined by (RI) violates axiom A.
The table of Figure 2 shows, for every AGM axiom, the characterizing property of frames. In Bonanno (2025) it is shown that the class F∗ of frames that satisfy the properties listed in Figure 2 characterizes the set of AGM belief revision functions in the following sense (for simplicity we omit the subscript M that refers to a given model; e.g. we write ||φ|| instead of ||φ||_M):
(A) For every model based on a frame in F, and for every state s in that model, the belief change function ◦ (based on K_{s} = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : B(s) \u2286 ||φ||} and Ψ = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : ||φ|| ≠ 0}) defined by (RI) can be extended to a full-domain belief revision function * that satisfies the AGM axioms (K * 1)-(K * 8).
(B) Let K \u2286 \u03a6₀ be a consistent and deductively closed set and let * : \u03a6₀ → 2^Φ₀ be a belief revision function based on K that satisfies the AGM axioms

sections.content:
(K*1)-(K*8). Then there exists a frame in F*, a model based on that frame and a state s in that model such that (1) K = K_s = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : B(s) \u2286 ||φ||} and (2) the partial belief change function ◦ (based on K, and and Ψ = {φ ∈ \u03a6₀ : ||φ|| ≠ 0}) defined by (RI) is such that K_{s} ◦ φ = K_s * φ for every consistent formula φ.
The characterization for (K * 4), (K * 7) and (K * 8) is proved in Propositions 9, 3 and 10, respectively, in Bonanno (2025). For the remaining axioms we note the following.
• Validity of (K * 1) on all frames is a consequence of Part (B) of Lemma 1 in Bonanno (2025).
• Sufficiency for (K * 2) is proved in Item 2 of Proposition 1 in Bonanno (2025). For necessity, consider a frame that violates Property (P * 2), that is, there exist s ∈ S, Ø ≠ E \u2286 S and s′ ∈ B(s) such that f(s′,E) ⊈ E. Construct a model where, for some atomic sentence p, ||p|| = E. Then, since f(s′, ||p||) ⊈ ||p|| and s′ ∈ B(s), p ∉ K_s * p, yielding a violation of (K * 2).
• The proof for (K * 3) is as follows.
(A) Sufficiency. Consider a model based on a frame that satisfies Property (P * 3). Let φ ∈ \u03a6₀ be such that ||φ|| ≠ Ø and let s ∈ S and ψ ∈ \u03a6₀ be such that ψ ∈ K_s * φ, that is, for every s′ ∈ B(s), f(s′, ||φ||) \u2286 ||ψ||, so that \bigcup_{x ∈ B(s)}f(x, ||φ||) \u2286 ||ψ||. Fix an arbitrary s′ ∈ B(s). If s′ ∉ ||φ|| (that is, s′ ⊨ ¬φ) then s′ ⊨ (φ → ψ). If s′ ∈ ||φ||, then by Property (P * 3), s′ ∈ \bigcup_{x ∈ B(s)}f(x, ||φ||) and hence s′ ∈ ||ψ||; thus s′ ⊨ (φ → ψ). It follows that (φ → ψ) ∈ K_s and thus ψ ∈ K_s + φ (since, by Lemma 2 in Bonanno (2025), K_s is deductively closed).
(B) Necessity. Consider a frame that violates (P * 3), that is, there exist s ∈ S, s′ ∈ B(s) and E \u2286 S such that s′ ∈ E and s′ ∉ \bigcup_{x ∈ B(s)}f(x, E). Construct a model based on this frame where, for some atomic sentences p and q, ||p|| = E and ||q|| = \bigcup_{x ∈ B(s)}f(x, E) = \bigcup_{x ∈ B(s)}f(x, ||p||). Then, for every x ∈ B(s), f(x, ||p||) \u2286 ||q|| so that q ∈ K_s * p. Since s′ ∈ ||p|| and s′ ∉ ||q||, s′ ⊭ (p → q) from which it follows (since s′ ∈ B(s)) that (p → q) ∉ K_s and thus q ∉ K_s + p. Hence K_s * p ⊈ K_s + p.

sections.title: A modal logic for belief revision
sections.content:
We now introduce a simple language with three modal operators: a unimodal belief operator B, a bimodal conditional operator > and the unimodal global operator \u25a1. The interpretation of Bφ is “the agent believes φ”, the interpretation of φ > ψ is “if φ is (or were) the case then ψ is (or would be) the case” and the interpretation of □φ is “φ is necessarily true”.
The set Φ of formulas in the language is defined as follows.
• Let \u03a6₀ be the set of Boolean formulas defined in Section 2.
• Let Φ_> be the set of formulas of the form φ > ψ with φ, ψ ∈ \u03a6₀.
• Let Φ₁ be the set of Boolean combinations of formulas in \u03a6₀ ∪ Φ_>.
• Let Φ_B be the set of formulas of the form Bφ with φ ∈ Φ₁.
• Let Φ_□ be the set of formulas of the form □φ with φ ∈ \u03a6₀.
• Finally, let Φ be the set of Boolean combinations of formulas in Φ₁ ∪ Φ_B ∪ Φ_□.

sections.title: Kripke-Lewis semantics
sections.content:
As semantics for this modal logic we take the Kripke-Lewis frames of Definition 2.3. A model based on a frame is obtained, as before, by adding a valuation V : At → 2^S. The following definition expands Definition 2.4 by adding validation rules for formulas of the form □φ, φ > ψ and Bφ.
Definition 3.1. Truth of a formula φ at state s in model M (denoted by s ⊨_M φ) is defined as follows:
1. if p e At then s ⊨_M p if and only if s ∈ V(p).
2. For φ ∈ Φ, s ⊨_M ¬φ if and only if s⊭_M φ.
3. φ ∈ Φ, s ⊨_M (φ ∨ ψ) if and only if s ⊨_M φ or s ⊨_M ψ (or both).
4. For φ ∈ \u03a6₀, s ⊨_M □φ if and only if, ∀s′ e S, s′ ⊨_M φ (thus s ⊨_M ¬□¬φ if and only if, for some s′ ∈ S, s′ ⊨_M φ).
5. For φ, ψ ∈ \u03a6₀, s ⊨_M (φ > ψ) if and only if, either
(a) s ⊨_M □¬φ (that is, ||φ||_M = Ø), or
(b) s ⊨_M ¬□¬φ (that is, ||φ||_M ≠ Ø) and, for every s′ ∈ f(s, ||φ||_M), s′ ⊨_M ψ (that is, f(s, ||φ||_M) \u2286 ||ψ||_M).
6. For φ ∈ Φ₁, s ⊨_M Bφ if and only if, ∀s′ ∈ B(s), s′ ⊨_M φ (that is, B(s) \u2286 ||φ||_M).
The definition of validity is as in the previous section.
Definition 3.2. A formula φ ∈ Φ is valid on a frame F if, for every model M based on that frame and for every state s in that model, s ⊨_M φ. A formula φ ∈ Φ is valid on a set of frames F if it is valid on every frame F ∈ F.
The definition of frame correspondence is the standard definition in modal logic.
Definition 3.3. A formula φ ∈ Φ is characterized by, or corresponds to, or characterizes, a property P of frames if the following is true:
(1) φ is valid on the class of frames that satisfy property P, and

sections.title: Frame correspondence
sections.content:
which is valid on all the frames considered in this paper.
• AGM axiom (K*5a) (if φ is a contradiction, then K*φ = Φ₀) can be captured in our logic by the following rule of inference: if ¬φ is a tautology (a theorem of propositional calculus) then B(φ > ψ) is a theorem.
• AGM axiom (K * 6) (if φ ↔ ψ is a tautology then K * φ = K * ψ) can be captured in our logic by the following rule of inference: if φ ↔ ψ is a tautology then B(φ > χ) ↔ B(ψ > χ) is a theorem (for φ, ψ, χ ∈ Φ₀), which is clearly validity preserving in every model, since if φ ↔ ψ is a tautology then ||φ|| = ||ψ||.
The table in Figure 3 synthesizes Figures 1 and 2 by showing the correspondence between each AGM axiom and its modal counterpart.

sections.title: Related literature
sections.content: A connection between conditional logic and AGM belief revision has been pointed out in several contributions, in particular Giordano et al. (1998; 2001; 2005), Günther and Sisti (2022). Although there are some similarities between our approach and those contributions, there are also some important differences. For a detailed discussion see Bonanno (2025).

sections.title: Appendix
sections.content:
Proposition 1. The modal axiom
B(φ > φ) (φ ∈ Φ₀)
is characterized by the following property of frames:
∀s ∈ S, ∀E ∈ 2^S \ {∅}, ∀s′ ∈ B(s), f(s′, E) ⊆ E.
Proof. First we show that Axiom (A2) is valid on every frame that satisfies Property (P * 2). Fix a model based on a frame that satisfies Property (P * 2), arbitrary s ∈ S, φ ∈ Φ₀ and s′ ∈ B(s); we need to show that s′ ⊨ (φ > φ). If ||φ|| = Ø, then, by (a) of Item 5 of Definition 3.1, s′ ⊨ (φ > φ). If ||φ|| ≠ 0 then, by Property (P * 2), f(s′, ||φ||) ⊆ ||φ|| and thus, by (b) of Item 5 of Definition 3.1, s′ ⊨ (φ > φ).
Next we show that Axiom (A2) is not valid on a frame that violates Property (P * 2). Fix such a frame, that is, a frame where there exist s ∈ S, Ø ≠ E ⊆ S and s′ ∈ B(s) such that f(s′, E) ⊈ E. Let p ∈ At be an atomic formula and construct a model based on this frame where ||p|| = E ≠ Ø. Then, since f(s′, ||p||) ⊈ ||p||, s′ ⊭ (p > p) and thus s ⊭ B(p > p) so that axiom (A2) is not valid on the given frame.
Proposition 2. The modal axiom
(¬□¬φ ∧ B(φ > ψ) → B(φ → ψ) (φ, ψ ∈ Φ₀)
is characterized by the following property of frames:
∀s ∈ S, ∀E ∈ 2^S \ {∅}, ∀s′ ∈ B(s), if s′ ∈ E then s′e ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, E).
Proof. First we show that Axiom (A3) is valid on every frame that satisfies Property (P * 3). Fix a model based on a frame that satisfies Property (P * 3), arbitrary s ∈ S and φ, ψ ∈ Φ₁ and suppose that s ⊨ ¬□¬φ ∧ B(φ > ψ). We need to show that s ⊨ B(φ → ψ). Since s ⊨ ¬□¬φ, ||φ|| ≠ Ø. Thus, since s ⊨ B(φ > ψ), ∀s′ ∈ B(s), f(s′, ||φ||) ⊆ ||ψ||. It follows that
∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, ||φ||) ⊆ ||ψ||.

Fix an arbitrary s′ ∈ B(s). Is s′ ∉ ||φ|| then s′ ⊨ φ → ψ. If s′ ∈ ||φ||, then by Property (P * 3), s′ ∈ ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, ||φ||) and thus, by (1), s′ ∈ ||ψ||, so that s′ ⊨ φ → ψ. Hence s ⊨ B(φ → ψ).
Next we show that Axiom (A3) is not valid on a frame that violates Property (P * 3). Fix such a frame, that is, a frame where there exist s ∈ S, Ø ≠ E ⊆ S and s′ ∈ B(s) such that s′ ∈ E but s′ ∉ ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, E). Let p, q ∈ At and construct a model based on this frame where ||p|| = E and ||q|| = ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, E) = ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, ||p||). Then s′ ⊨ p but s′ ⊭ q, so that s′ ⊭ p → q, from which it follows that s ⊭ B(p → q), that is, s ⊨ ¬B(p → q). To obtain a violation of (A3) it only remains to show that s ⊨ ¬□¬p ∧ B(p > q). That s ⊨ ¬□¬p is a consequence of the fact that, by hypothesis, Ø ≠ E = ||p||. Furthermore, since ||p|| ≠ Ø and ||q|| = ∪_{x ∈ B(s)} f(x, ||p||), for every y ∈ B(s), f(y,||p||) ⊆ ||q|| and therefore y ⊨ (p > q), so that s ⊨ B(p > q).
Proposition 3. The modal axiom
(¬B¬φ ∧ B(φ → ψ)) → B(φ > ψ) (φ, ψ ∈ Φ₀)
is characterized by the following property of frames:
∀s ∈ S, ∀E ∈ 2^S \ {∅}, if B(s) ∩ E ≠ Ø then, ∀s′ ∈ B(s), f(s′, E) ⊆ B(s) ∩ E.
Proof. First we show that Axiom (A4) is valid on every frame that satisfies Property (P * 4). Fix a model based on a frame that satisfies Property (P * 4), an arbitrary s ∈ S and arbitrary φ, ψ ∈ Φ₀ and suppose that s ⊨ ¬B¬φ ∧ B(φ → ψ). We need to show that s ⊨ B(φ > ψ). Since s ⊨ ¬B¬φ, there exists an s′ ∈ B(s) such that s′ ⊨ φ, that is, B(s) ∩ ||φ|| ≠ Ø. Thus, by Property (P * 4), ∀s′ ∈ B(s), f(s′, ||φ||) ⊆ B(s) ∩ ||ψ||.
Since s ⊨ B(φ → ψ), B(s) ⊆ ||φ → ψ|| = ||¬φ|| ∪ ||ψ||. Hence
f(s′, ||φ||) ⊆ ||¬φ|| ∪ ||ψ|| = ||φ|| ∪ (||ψ|| ∩ ||φ||) ⊆ ||φ|| ∪ B(s) ⊆ ||ψ||

Proof. First we show that Axiom (A7) is valid on every frame that satisfies Property (P * 7). Fix a model based on a frame that satisfies Property (P * 7), arbitrary s ∈ S and φ, ψ, χ ∈ Φ₁ and suppose thats = ¬□¬(φ∧ψ) ∧ B((φ∧ψ) > χ).
